FLUTICASONE

CORTICOSTEROIDS (TOPICAL)CORTICOSTEROIDS (INTRANASAL)CORTICOSTEROIDS (INHALED)

  • Side effects
  • Administration
  • Patient and carer advice

Indications and doses

Prophylaxis of asthma,

By inhalation of nebulised suspension

  • For adults
    Initially 100–500 micrograms twice daily (max. per dose 1 mg twice daily), dose may be increased according to severity of asthma. Doses above 500 micrograms twice daily initiated by a specialist.
  • For adults
    Initially 100–500 micrograms twice daily (max. per dose 1 mg twice daily), dose may be increased according to severity of asthma. Doses above 500 micrograms twice daily initiated by a specialist.
  • For adults
    0.5–2 mg twice daily.
  • For children 5–15 years
    Initially 50–100 micrograms twice daily (max. per dose 200 micrograms twice daily), dose to be adjusted as necessary.
  • For children 16–17 years
    Initially 100–500 micrograms twice daily (max. per dose 1 mg twice daily), dose may be increased according to severity of asthma. Doses above 500 micrograms twice daily initiated by a specialist.
  • For children 4–15 years
    Initially 50–100 micrograms twice daily (max. per dose 200 micrograms twice daily), dose to be adjusted as necessary.
  • For children 16–17 years
    Initially 100–500 micrograms twice daily (max. per dose 1 mg twice daily), dose may be increased according to severity of asthma. Doses above 500 micrograms twice daily initiated by a specialist.
  • For children 4–15 years
    1 mg twice daily.
  • For children 16–17 years
    0.5–2 mg twice daily.

Prophylaxis and treatment of allergic rhinitis and perennial rhinitis,

By intranasal administration using nasal spray

  • For adults
    100 micrograms once daily, to be administered into each nostril preferably in the morning, increased if necessary to 100 micrograms twice daily; reduced to 50 micrograms once daily, dose to be administered into each nostril, dose to be reduced when control achieved.
  • For children 4–11 years
    50 micrograms once daily, to be administered into each nostril preferably in the morning, increased if necessary to 50 micrograms twice daily.
  • For children 12–17 years
    100 micrograms once daily, to be administered into each nostril preferably in the morning, increased if necessary to 100 micrograms twice daily; reduced to 50 micrograms once daily, dose to be administered into each nostril, dose to be reduced when control achieved.

Nasal polyps,

By intranasal administration using nasal drops

  • For adults
    200 micrograms 1–2 times a day, to be administered into each nostril, dose of 200 micrograms approximately 6 drops, alternative treatment should be considered if no improvement after 4–6 weeks.
  • For children 16–17 years
    200 micrograms 1–2 times a day, to be administered into each nostril, dose of 200 micrograms approximately 6 drops, alternative treatment should be considered if no improvement after 4–6 weeks.

Severe inflammatory skin disorders such as dermatitis and eczemas unresponsive to less potent corticosteroids, Psoriasis,

To the skin

  • For adults
    Apply 1–2 times a day, to be applied thinly.
  • For children 3 months–17 years
    Apply 1–2 times a day, to be applied thinly.

Potency of preperations

Fluticasone cream 0.05%: potent.

Fluticasone ointment 0.005%: potent.

Known side effects

Specific side effects

notKnown: arthralgia, dyspepsia,

Nasal ulceration

Nasal ulceration occurs commonly with nasal preparations containing fluticasone furoate.

Directions for administration

When used by inhalation

Fluticasone nebuliser liquid may be diluted with sterile sodium chloride 0.9%. It is not suitable for use in ultrasonic nebulisers.

Advice for patients and carers

When used by inhalation

Patients or carers should be given advice on how to administer all fluticasone inhalations preparations.

With topical use

Patients or carers should be given advice on application of fluticasone creams and ointments,

When used by inhalation

With high doses, a steroid card should be supplied.

In children

Medicines for Children leaflet: Fluticasone inhaler for asthma prevention (prophylaxis)

www.medicinesforchildren.org.uk/fluticasone-inhaler-for-asthma-prevention

National funding/access decisions

Unlicensed use

With topical use in children

Not licensed for use in children under 3 months.

Exceptions to legal category

With intranasal use in adults

Preparations of fluticasone propionate can be sold to the public for nasal administration (other than by pressurised nasal spray) if supplied for the prevention and treatment of allergic rhinitis in adults over 18 years, subject to max. single dose of 100 micrograms per nostril, max. daily dose of 200 micrograms per nostril for max. 3 months, and a pack size of 3 mg.

Prepared medicinal forms of FLUTICASONE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Pressurised inhalation
Inhalation powder
Nebuliser liquid
Cream
Ointment
Spray
Nasal drops
